The '''Estonian resistance movement''' ([[Estonian language|Estonian]] ''Eesti vastupanuliikumine'') was an [[resistance during World War II|underground]] [[Political movement|movement]] to [[Resistance during World War II|resist]] the [[occupation of Estonia by Nazi Germany]], 1941–1944 during [[World War II]]. Due to the unusually benign measures implemented in [[Estonia]] by the German [[Military occupation|occupation]] authorities, especially in contrast to the preceding harsh [[Occupation of Baltic Republics|Soviet occupation of Estonia]] (1940–1941), the movement was slower to develop effective tactics on a wide scale than in other occupied countries.
==Background==
[[File:RiigiTeataja20091944.jpg|thumb|250px|The September 18, 1944 appointed [[Government of Estonia]] in [[Riigi Teataja]]]] While there was a general mood of gratitude towards Germany as the liberator of Estonia from Soviet occupation, this reservoir of goodwill dissipated within the first months of the war and was transformed into a mood ranging from resigned indifference to active hostility.<ref name='Misiunas'>{{cite book |title=The Baltic States, years of dependence, 1940-1980 |last=Misiunas |first=Romuald J. |authorlink= |author2=Rein Taagepera |author3=Georg von Rauch |year=2010 |publisher=University of California Press |location= |isbn=978-0-520-04625-2|page=62 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> Professor Uluots' request to the German occupation authorities for the establishment of an independent Estonian Government was rejected and [[Adolf Hitler]] subsequently appointed [[Alfred Rosenberg]] as Reichkommissar.<ref name='Rauch'>{{cite book |title=Die Geschichte der baltischen Staaten |last=von Rauch |first=Georg |authorlink= |year=1974 |publisher=University of California Press |location= |isbn=978-0-520-02600-1 |page= |pages=229–230 |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> After it became clear that the Germans were against the restoration of independence of the Estonian state, this negative relationship between the new occupiers and the occupied was sealed.<ref name='Misiunas'/> Public resentment began to grow against Germany from 1942 with the imposition of conscription for men into the police battalions, the introduction of the labour draft and the reduction of food rations, while the [[Estonian Self-Administration]] was held in contempt for attempting to enforce this conscription.<ref name='Statiev'>{{cite book |title=The Soviet Counterinsurgency in the Western Borderlands |last=Statiev |first=Alexander |authorlink= |year=2010 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location= |isbn=978-0-521-76833-7 |page=90 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> [[Hjalmar Mäe]], the head of the Self-Administration, became quickly unpopular for his criticism of President [[Konstantin Päts]].<ref>''Eesti ajalugu VI''. Tartu 2005. p. 200.</ref> He had been imprisoned by Päts' regime in 1935 for taking part of an alleged coup.<ref>{{cite book |title=The radical right in interwar Estonia |last=Kasekamp |first=Andres |authorlink= |year=2000 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |location= |isbn=978-0-312-22598-8 |page=136 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> Germans offered his position several times to [[Jüri Uluots]], who refused.<ref>''Eesti ajalugu VI''. Tartu 2005. p. 199.</ref>
The Estonian people regarded German occupation with greater bitterness than the previous [[Occupation of Estonia by the German Empire|1917–1918 German occupation]] and were repelled by the implementation of the German race laws and the insouciant exploitation of the country's natural resources.<ref name='Rauch'/> One Dutch Nazi visiting Estonia in June 1942 commented upon the "chauvinist national consciousness" of the Estonian people and no genuine Germanophile could be found.<ref name='Misiunas'/>
==Pro-independence resistance== An underground resistance movement,<ref name='Smith'/> whose members looked to the western Allies for support,<ref name='Rauch'/> developed that reflected the political divisions that existed before 1940, ranging from Päts loyalists to the opposition groups such as the National Centre and Socialist Workers parties. The resistance, which was expressed through a campaign of non-compliance co-ordinated by the underground movement and a clandestine press,<ref name='Smith'/> was favoured by the geographical proximity to Sweden and Finland where the organised political resistance in Tartu and Tallinn were able to maintain contact with London and Stockholm via the Estonian Envoy to Finland and a fortnightly fast motorboat connection between Tallinn and Stockholm.<ref>Misiunas p66</ref>
Initially a number of underground organisations existed such as the [[Free Estonia Front]] (Vaba Eesti Võitlusrinne, VEVR) which was established in August 1942 and headed by [[Juhan Reigo]] and [[Endel Inglist]]. The VEVR published an anti-Nazi newspaper ''Vaba Eesti'' (Free Estonia), issuing 14 editions.<ref name='Hiio09'/> Another underground newspaper titled ''Võitlev Eestlane'' (Fighting Estonian) was published by a group within the editorial staff of the newspaper [[Postimees]]. In the autumn of 1941, the precursor to the National Committee of the Republic of Estonia was founded by [[Heinrich Mark]], [[Ants Oras]] and [[Jaan Ots]]. The organisation was headed by [[Ernst Kull]] in 1943 and it was through his efforts that the various groups were merged into a unified opposition to Nazi rule.<ref name='Hiio09'>{{cite book |title=Estonia since 1944: Reports of the Estonian International Commission for the Investigation of Crimes Against Humanity |last=Hiio |first=Toomas |authorlink= |year=2009 |publisher=Estonian Foundation for the Investigation of Crimes Against Humanity |location= |isbn=978-9949-18-300-5 |page= |pages=377–378 |url= |accessdate=}}</ref>
In June 1942 political leaders of Estonia who had survived Soviet repressions held a hidden meeting from the occupying powers in Estonia where the formation of an underground Estonian government and the options for preserving continuity of the republic were discussed.<ref name="EIHC">[http://www.historycommission.ee/temp/pdf/tables/chronology.pdf Chronology] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609224537/http://www.historycommission.ee/temp/pdf/tables/chronology.pdf |date=June 9, 2007 }} at the EIHC</ref> On January 6, 1943 a meeting was held at the Estonian foreign delegation in Stockholm. It was decided that, in order to preserve the legal continuity of the [[Republic of Estonia]], the last constitutional prime minister, Jüri Uluots, must continue to fulfill his responsibilities as prime minister.<ref name="EIHC"/><ref name="mälksoo">Mälksoo, Lauri (2000). [http://www.springerlink.com/content/3e5hl9ux79vj213x/ Professor Uluots, the Estonian Government in Exile and the Continuity of the Republic of Estonia in International Law]. ''[[Nordic Journal of International Law]]'' 69.3, 289–316.</ref>
The movement subsequently formed the [[National Committee of the Republic of Estonia]] ({{Lang-et|Eesti Vabariigi Rahvuskomitee}}) in March 1944.<ref name='Smith'>{{cite book |title=Estonia: Independence and European Integration |last=Smith |first=David James |authorlink= |year=2001 |publisher=Routledge |location= |isbn=978-0-415-26728-1 |pages=36 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lx-UmTnLJv0C&pg=PA36&dq }}</ref> The original initiative to form the committee came from the Estonian pre-war opposition parties but it was quickly joined by [[Jüri Uluots]], the last constitutional pre-war Prime Minister of the Republic of Estonia and his supporters. The Committee aimed to establish a provisional government during expected German withdrawal as the Red Army had [[Kingisepp-Gdov Offensive|reached the border of Estonia]] on 2 February 1944. By April 1944 a large number of the committee members were arrested by the German security agencies.<ref>{{cite book |title=Historical Dictionary of Estonia |last=Miljan |first=Toivo |authorlink= |year=2004 |publisher=Scarecrow Press |location= |isbn=978-0-8108-4904-4 |pages=21 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XKWRct15XfkC&pg=PA21&dq }}</ref> While some 200 people were arrested, the leaders of the resistance movement escaped arrest however their activities were severely curtailed until mid June.<ref>{{cite book |title=Estonia and the Estonians |last=Raun |first=Toivo U. |authorlink= |year=2001 |publisher=Hoover Press |location= |isbn=978-0-8179-2852-0 |page=163 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> In June 1944 the elector’s assembly of the Republic of Estonia gathered in secrecy from the occupying powers in Tallinn and appointed Jüri Uluots as the prime minister with the responsibilities of the President. On 21 June 1944 Jüri Uluots appointed [[Otto Tief]] as deputy prime minister.<ref name="EIHC"/> On 18 September 1944 Uluots, suffering from cancer, named Otto Tief the Acting Prime Minister and appointed a Government which consisted of 11 members. Tief assumed office in accordance with the constitution and took the opportunity with the departure of the Germans to declare the legitimate Estonian government restored. The Estonian national government was proclaimed in Estonia, the Estonian military units seized the government buildings in [[Toompea]] and ordered the German forces to leave.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=cm01R5fMF5SysgP38dmFAg&id=V4siAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22Otto+Tief+%22&q=Otto+Tief&pgis=1#search By Royal Institute of International Affairs. Information Dept. Published 1945]</ref> The flag of Germany was replaced with the [[Flag of Estonia|Estonian tricolour]] in the [[Pikk Hermann]], the flag tower of the seat of the Government. Tief’s government failed to keep control, attempting to organise the defence of the capital city against the advancing Red Army making use of the men who had fought in the [[Finnish Infantry Regiment 200]] and a military unit organised by [[Johan Pitka]],<ref>{{cite book |title=History of Estonia |last=Laur |first=Mati |authorlink= |year=2000 |publisher=Avita |location= |isbn=978-9985-2-0324-8|page=275 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> the Germans overran the headquarters of Admiral Pitka in Tallinn and he was subsequently killed in the ensuing battle.<ref>{{cite book |title=Estonia, 1940-1945: Reports of the Estonian International Commission for the Investigation of Crimes Against Humanity |last=Hiio |first=Toomas |authorlink= |year=2006 |publisher=Estonian Foundation for the Investigation of Crimes Against Humanity |location= |isbn=978-9949-13-040-5 |page=1099 |pages= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> Most of the members and officials were caught, jailed, deported, or executed by the advancing Soviets.
==[[Soviet partisans in Estonia|Pro-Soviet resistance]]== A small number of Estonians were involved in underground [[resistance during World War II]] ranging from producing illegal publications, to [[espionage]], to violent [[sabotage]]. They included Rein Alasoo,<ref>[http://www.elukiri.ee/0608/esileht/10075126.php Valve Raudnask, Rõõmus eluga toimetulek.]</ref> [[Evald Laasi]],<ref>[[Suure võitluse algus]], compiled by [[Karl Mang]] & [[August Pähklimägi]], [[Tallinn]], 1965, p. 73-79.</ref> Georgi Loik,<ref>[http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:xfQ1RiXc2iAJ:www.abc-poessneck.de/aktion/durchgefuehrt_2006/zeitzeuge_100406/vorstellung_zeitzeuge.pdf+%22Georgi+Loik%22&cd=2&hl=en&ct=clnk Georgi Karl Loik.]</ref><ref>[http://www.abacho.com/mobile/news/politik/anzeigen/?news_id=37847 «Ich habe den Anzug seit der Befreiung nicht mehr gewaschen»]</ref> Aleksander Looring,<ref>[http://www.velise.ee/seltsid/4.html Velise Algkooli Karskusringi Vilistlaskogu.]</ref><ref>[http://www.fl.ut.ee/199199 Läänemaalane Aleksander Looring 1905. aasta ajaloo uurijana.]</ref> as well as others.<ref>{{Cite book |publisher = Eesti Riiklik Kirjastus |publication-place = Estonia |author = Rudolf Lumi |ol = 24377325M |title = Rahvatasujad (1. osa) |publication-date = 1962 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |publisher = Eesti Raamat |publication-place = Tallinn, Estonia |author = Rudolf Lumi |ol = 24377333M |title = Rahvatasujad (2. osa) |publication-date = 1965 }}</ref>
